en.value: Answering the question "How was your day?" with basic adjectives - Past simple of the verb "to be"
Read and listen to the words.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Read and listen to the word and the key phrase.
If you've had a fairly relaxing day, or if you haven't done much, you can say that your day was "pretty chilled".
Select the words in the correct order.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Patricia and Manuel are catching up at work.
Yeah, but my afternoon was quite [k]chilled[/k].
Yeah, it was [k]lovely[/k], thank you. Really fun.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Select the negative words from the list.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
It was really busy, but very [k]productive[/k].
Sophie had a great day. Type the correct word.
Write or record a response to the question "How was your day?".
Grammar: Past simple - The verb "to be"

Now we’re going to learn to talk about things that happened in the past. To do that, we need a new tense: the past simple (the past simple). For now, we’re just going to learn the past simple form of the verb “to be”.
The verb "to be" has two forms in the past simple tense: was and were.
Select the past forms of the verb "to be".

To form a question, we change the word order in the sentence by placing the verb "to be" at the beginning. If there is a question word, we put it before the verb. What / Why / Where / When / How + was / were + subject (personal pronoun / noun) ...?
To make a question, we need to bring "was / were" to the beginning.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
To make the statement negative, we add "not" after "was" or "were". In speech, we usually shorten it using an apostrophe.
They [k]weren't[/k] at home yesterday. They were at the park.
To recap, have a look at all the forms again.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Where were Mike and Susan last night?
How was Margaret feeling last night?
When we talk about actions in the past we often add time phrases to give more information about when the action happened.
I [k]was[/k] on holiday in Turkey [k]last summer[/k].
We were at home last night.
We [k]were not|weren't[/k] at home last night.
Complete the question to ask Mike where he was this morning.
I'm sorry, I [k]was quite stressed[/k] this morning.
Fill in the gap using the image.
In 2008, [k]they were|we were|you were|I was[/k] at university.
